Ted Striker.Action: Test-piloted the shuttle and told the truth about its safety despite negative consequences.
Determines he must stop the flight and acts on it by pushing through the crowd to take immediate action.
Asks where mission control is but receives no clear direction and seems puzzled yet continues moving forward.
Passes through various classes of travelers and approaches the information counter to ask for mission control directions.
Questions the info agent about mission control's location despite unclear or unhelpful responses and the agent's eventual shooting.
Pulls away from Elaine when she shows concern, blaming others instead of accepting support.
Rants about his work and tries to prove his point with flight designs, showing determination and sincerity.
Rants about design specifications and tries to prove his point by grabbing plans, showing some technical knowledge and concern for details.
Is perceived by others as overworked and possibly having a breakdown; struggles against guards and is forcibly sedated, indicating loss of control and inability to handle stress effectively.
Rejects Elaine’s attempt to calm him down and lashes out, showing emotional instability and poor interpersonal skills.
Muttering to himself and insisting he is perfectly sane despite evidence to the contrary.
Engages briefly and politely with Stella Barrington, demonstrating basic social awareness and some knowledge about Dr. Barrington's work.
Abruptly excuses himself and leaves without further interaction, possibly avoiding engagement or responsibility.

Insists on seeing Bud Kruger urgently despite lacking an appointment, uses humor in stress (matter of life or death, then 'matter of death'), disregards receptionist's authority momentarily to proceed.
Rushes into mission control without appointment, insists urgently to see Bud Kruger despite receptionist's objections.
Fails to realize he is grabbing a false door knob on the wall and attempts to enter through it.
Struggles to free his hands when tied to a chair, but does not successfully escape and remains captive.
Observes the cigarette rolling towards oil rags and an explosive drum, potentially indicating situational awareness.
Survives explosion from the storage room, gets up, brushes himself off, and immediately proceeds to try to secure a ticket.
Moves toward Elaine with urgency to stop the flight, speaks sincerely about his need to intervene.
Attempts to enter cockpit despite resistance, showing concern for others' safety.
Does not show hostility towards Mary or Elaine despite being blocked and locked out.
Attempts to reach Elaine and stop the flight despite obstacles.
Fails to get into the cockpit as Elaine locks the door on him.
Refuses to admit that he's sick despite obvious problems.
Refuses to admit that he's sick despite evident problems affecting his brain function.
Ted tries the door and calls out firmly, showing some initiative and assertiveness.
Distractedly accepts a magazine from Mary without engaging in conversation.
Breathes deeply on an oxygen unit, appears anxious but not interacting with others.
Breathes deeply on an oxygen unit, showing attempts to steady himself.
Expresses concern to Elaine about the safety of the ship and insists the mission must be aborted.
Tries to hold himself back and escape the malfunctioning washroom situation calmly.
Attempts to engage Elaine, showing he values her opinion and tries to communicate sincerely.
Expresses diagnosis about the ship's dangerously faulty wiring and perceives the toilet incident as a symptom of larger issues.
Walks down the aisle checking overhead panels, displaying attentiveness to his environment.
Open a half-open panel labeled 'DANGER -- VACUUM,' resulting in a Hoover falling on his head and causing injury.
Uses a handkerchief to hold a wound and continues moving rather than immediately addressing injury.
Engages in a thoughtful, reflective conversation about love and relationships, showing emotional insight and introspection.
Recounts emotional memories with Elaine, conveying depth of feeling and continuity despite hardship.
Locked in each other's arms with Stella, laughing their heads off during lovemaking.
Narrates their story sincerely, showing closeness and affection.
Passengers hiss and throw vegetables at Ted after his story.
Tells a story calmly to passengers despite them reacting negatively (hissing and throwing vegetables)
Takes stress pills automatically when suggested.
Misses his face with his drink while trying to take the pill.
Elaine confirms 'Then Ted was right!' indicating Ted had correctly anticipated the danger and his assessment is validated.
No direct action, skill, or decision by Ted Striker in this excerpt; mostly passengers and Elaine speak and react.
Lost in thought reflecting on past trauma and psychosis, showing vulnerability.
Does not engage in conversation when Jimmy offers to talk, appearing withdrawn.
Ignores a chaotic scene (piano smashing) nearby and just gives Gloria and Cab a quizzical look.
Travels at night in shadows, avoids attracting attention, afraid to step out and interact.
Bends down to pick up a wet matchbook after being sprayed with garbage.
Acknowledges attraction when noticing a woman's legs and responds to her lighting his cigarette.
Communicates calmly and clearly about a serious technical problem to the crew and passengers.
Mentions the lack of coffee and general discomfort in a somewhat humorous tone.
Focuses on managing the crisis rather than expressing personal emotion or connection.
Writes a note to Elaine to coordinate action against the malfunctioning computer, showing teamwork and concern.
Tells Elaine to hold the controls and advises her to try best, demonstrating trust and encouragement.
Leaves to deal with the dangerous situation himself despite risk, indicating protective and responsible behavior.
Takes apart the coffee machine and attempts technical repair under pressure while communicating with mission control.
Does not fully prevent the system from overheating despite warnings and consequences.
Accurately recognizes that they are closer to the sun than estimated by the computer, showing situational awareness.
Takes control of the radio communication and confidently challenges Mission Control’s decisions and calls out their mistakes.
Misinterprets Elaine's statement about time left until burning up, thinking she means something else.
Defends a compassionate stance on radio, expressing concern about spending priorities to help low cost housing.
Expresses hope and confidence with Elaine despite crisis situation.
Immediately informs Mary about the bomb threat to warn others.
Wears gas mask and securely attaches a time-bomb to the computer despite hazardous conditions.
Responds honestly to Elaine's question about fear, admitting it would be foolish not to be afraid in the situation.
Shows calm leadership when communicating with mission control and preparing to reprogram the ship before the bomb explodes.
Calmly assesses the dire situation and communicates clearly with mission control, indicating awareness and preparedness.
Acknowledges fear as a natural response but maintains composure, showing emotional intelligence under pressure.
Responds with a confident warning to Testa and takes charge of reprogramming the ship, indicating leadership and decisiveness.
Recalled by Rex Kramer as a crack pilot who was skilled during the war
Mentioned by Kramer to have failed to perform under pressure ('didn't have it in the crunch')
Implements a makeshift solution by using a bobby pin to short circuit wires and successfully slow the ship down.
Confused and madly looking around when told to find controls, initially unsure about available controls (switches, lights, knobs).
Overwhelmed by Elaine's seductive gesture and momentarily distracted.
Tries to keep the ship level and maintain control despite it bouncing wildly and fighting him.
Acknowledges difficulty by saying 'She's coming apart!' and 'I'm trying but she's fighting me!'
Allows a boxing glove to punch him in the face from the dashboard, indicating a moment of distraction or loss of control.
Fights the controls of the crashing ship despite front window being broken and debris everywhere.
Does not visibly hesitate or abandon control under extreme pressure and danger.
Successfully lands the ship on a difficult, smoky surface following radio instructions, keeping calm and steady under pressure.
Holds Elaine and shares a moment of reassurance after the crash, showing emotional steadiness.
Pauses to look into the distance contemplating their situation after the crash, suggesting thoughtful reflection rather than panic.
Shoos a bird away gently by knocking on the glass rather than harming it.
Drinks beer while flying, behaving cockily and recklessly, showing disregard for safety or responsibility.
Lies in a messy hotel room, drinking and smoking, showing signs of distress and possibly self-neglect but no direct antisocial behavior.
Shows a framed photo of himself with Elaine, suggesting attachment and capacity for emotional connection.
Shoos a bird off the fighter's nose while flying at high speed and successfully lands at a small Latin-American strip.
Wears his oxygen mask loosely, drinks beer while flying, and has beer spilled on himself indicating carelessness.
Reflects on his past failure and lost squadron with apparent resignation, showing emotional burden but some self-awareness.
Acknowledges his past fear and failures honestly in voice-over narration.
Accepts fate and takes responsibility to pilot a plane despite fear and no crew.
Observes irony and fame with a somewhat detached tone, showing humility.
Successfully lands a plane with no crew, becoming a hero and receiving public acclaim.
Avoids pigeons following him in the park, appears uneasy around birds.
Sweats and struggles to switch off a powerful table fan, causing destruction.
Passes travellers in rags and no interaction, simply heads for information counter.
Attempts to get information from uninterested Info Agent, shows mild persistence.
Looks directly into the camera with a deadpan expression after receiving unhelpful directions.
Insists the Mercury mission is unsafe based on his technical insight about wiring shorting out under high temperatures.
Accused by others of being 'still crazy' and 'sick', suggesting others doubt his mental stability and thereby his competence.
Puts effort into warning others and following up on potential safety issues despite social rejection.
His warning about wiring problems is dismissed as paranoia or mental illness by Simon, indicating Ted may be perceived as unreliable.
Responds politely to nurse Stella's offer of help but quickly excuses himself and leaves.
Pursues Elaine persistently despite her reluctance and explains his feelings, showing emotional vulnerability.
Ignores Elaine's request to return to the hospital and insists on going to mission control, demonstrating stubbornness.
Determines to go to mission control despite Elaine's discouragement.
Repeatedly pursues Elaine despite her rejection and clear preference for Simon, seeming unaware of social cues.
Has a flashback to being in a mental hospital, implying past psychological instability.
Turns away when Elaine tries to kiss him; tells Elaine not to say goodbyes and to just go
Shows reluctance and detachment during breakup, avoiding emotional connection
Ignores Elaine's attempts to communicate and help, focusing frantically on his task.
Ignores Elaine as he works frantically and feverishly on solving the shuttle problem.
Working out aggressively in the hospital garden, demonstrating focus and effort.
Refuses to be distracted or helped, telling Elaine 'Not now' when she tries to engage him.
Sits quietly, distracted, opens a smoking magazine, appears confused or unsettled.
Attempts to engage with reading material but is distracted and unresponsive to surroundings.
Throws water on his face and tries to compose himself before interacting with others.
Attempts to stop a malfunctioning toilet by hitting the handle but inadvertently makes it worse.
Recognizes the severity of the situation and insists the mission must be aborted due to unsafe conditions on the ship.
Communicates urgent concerns clearly to Elaine about the ship’s safety and the necessity to abort the mission.
Walks down the aisle checking overhead panels, investigates potential safety hazards.
Holds a hanky to his head wound and downplays injury to Stella.
Responds to Stella by acknowledging relationship difficulties sincerely.
Allows Stella to care for his head wound, showing trust and acceptance of help.
Openly discusses his confused feelings about love with Stella, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Reminisces warmly about laughing and shared love with Elaine, highlighting affection and good-natured memories.
Is lost in thought recalling his past struggles with mental health and his competence questioned by others.
Unable to immediately take control or act decisively when the crew is lost and Simon is incapacitated.
Turns away from the window and talks to the lamb in bed, showing a moment of kindness despite his own troubles.
Mentions finding out who your friends are when in trouble, implying some trust or recognition of loyalty.
Bols and escapes from the mental hospital wearing a straightjacket to avoid capture.
Travels cautiously at night in the shadows to avoid attracting attention, showing awareness of his surroundings and the dangers he faces.
Steps into light despite fear and potential danger, indicating some decisiveness.
Ignores a piano smashing to the pavement and does not react, showing composure but possibly lack of urgency or situational responsiveness.
Bends down to pick up a wet matchbook despite being sprayed with garbage, demonstrating resourcefulness or attention to detail.
Draws on cigarette after being offered a lighter by an unknown woman, showing calmness.
Borrows dark glasses from a blind man causing him to stumble and crash.
Takes an alto saxophone from a passerby who then stumbles and crashes.
Stays in the background to avoid drawing attention and admires Elaine's love of life.
Attempts to assert control and get Simon to take responsibility despite Simon's drunkenness; tries to pull Simon together to address the situation.
Falls into a corner and hits his head after being slugged by Simon, leading to unconsciousness.
Allows a puppy to crawl over and lick his face without resistance or irritation.
Responds politely and kindly to Jimmy's concern, reassuring him he feels fine.
Pushes by Jimmy with a look of great purpose, focusing on a goal rather than social interaction.
Lies unconscious and is non-responsive during a critical moment.
Wakes up, assesses himself quickly, and immediately moves with purpose toward the cockpit.
Reassures Elaine by saying 'We all make mistakes' and expresses his continued love for her despite past doubts.
Holds hands with Elaine, reconnecting emotionally in a stressful situation.
Drags an incapacitated crew member aside and takes the pilot seat confidently when the situation demands it.
Distracts from urgent radio calls by engaging in a sentimental exchange with Elaine instead of addressing the mission control's repeated calls.
Smiles at Elaine and responds warmly to her loving smile.
Communicates calmly and clearly over the radio despite tense situation.
Uses humor in radio communication ('sitting down and facing the front').
Hits a switch to do a barrel roll and attempts radio communication with mission control.
Responds to mission control's call with a somewhat humorous but clear identification.
Smiles and maintains composure in a tense situation.
Communicates clearly on the radio about critical failures and the dire situation aboard the ship.
Acknowledges inability to override computer controls to manual, indicating awareness of system failures.
Mentions crew losses and lack of coffee in a somewhat humorous or casual manner during a crisis.
Acknowledges McCrosky's pep talk but gently corrects him, expressing concern for the ship rather than himself.
Stands over the coffee machine, sweating nervously but manages to make electrical contact before the coffee machine explodes, causing a comical but seemingly successful outcome (coffee gusher)
Expresses frustration and anger over the danger to many lives and calls out Kruger for irresponsibility.
Misunderstands Elaine's comment and dismisses her prematurely.
Accepts responsibility to attempt a difficult maneuver to handle the bomb threat.
Shows calm and hopeful attitude when receiving updates and communicating over radio.
Gathers information quickly about the bomber passenger in order to assess threat.
Relies on ground control and others' thinking, showing some dependence on external solutions.
Calmly instructs Mary to discreetly move passengers and tries to prevent panic.
Extends his arms to hold back passengers from Joe, trying to keep them safe.
Speaks empathetically to Joe, trying to persuade him not to blow up the plane and reminding him about his family.
Reassures Joe that no one has to know what's wrong with him.
Despite being insulted by Jimmy, tackles Joe to prevent disaster.
Instructs Mary to discreetly move passengers to lounge, tries to calm and control the passengers, negotiates calmly with Joe to prevent him from detonating a bomb.
Fails to prevent the passengers from panicking after Mary announces a bomb, loses control of the situation when Joe bolts, requiring physical tackle.
Engages cooperatively with mission control despite extreme conditions (cockpit very hot, eggs frying on dash)
Responds to McCrosky's orders with a humorous remark about knocking out the wall and hanging plants
Expresses skepticism about using a bomb to solve the problem, showing careful consideration.
Responds to Elaine's concern and love, and chooses to go back to the cabin to handle the dangerous task, showing care and responsibility.
Verbalizes skepticism about a risky plan but proceeds to take responsibility by grabbing the bomb case and going back to the computer core to perform a dangerous task.
Shows hesitation initially by commenting 'Why, you'd have to be crazy to try a stunt like that.'
Calmly reassures Elaine during a crisis, tries to instill confidence in the plan.
Shows little empathy when describing Simon's fate in harsh terms ('roast like a pig on a spit').
Calmly takes control of the cockpit and explains the situation confidently to Elaine, asserting that Simon's ejection was premature and dangerous.
Refuses to panic despite the critical situation, showing confidence in the bomb trick working.
Demonstrates courage, dedication, selflessness, and spirit as praised by McCrosky.
Recognizes the failure of the computer and immediately instructs Elaine to set a course change, coordinating quickly with her.
Pulls the acceleration lever decisively to execute the evasive maneuver despite ship shaking and rough conditions.
Keeps calm under pressure, monitoring the speed and communicating clearly over radio.
Manually pilots the shuttle at zero point five WORP speed after losing computer control.
Described as 'top dog' and 'numero uno honcho' responsible for the shuttle's landing.
Fights to maintain control in a high-pressure situation despite technical failure.
Communicates clearly and honestly about the WORP control handle breaking off.
Maintains control of the cockpit under difficult conditions and follows Rex Kramer's instructions.
WORP control handle comes off in his hand during a critical maneuver.
Accepts Elaine's help and thanks her sincerely.
Focuses on problem solving under stress without dismissing others.
Does not display hostility or sarcasm when Kramer questions his use of a bobby pin from Elaine's hair.
Struggles to maintain control of the ship under extreme conditions and vocalizes urgency ('She's coming apart!', 'I'm trying but she's fighting me!')
Holds Elaine after a crash, comforting her and sharing a kiss amid chaos.
Walks off with Elaine into the distance after the crash, showing presence and support.
Pauses to look into the distant sky when Elaine asks what will happen, indicating thoughtful attention but no immediate reassurance.
